Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving the Generic Mapping Tools for Seismology, Geodesy, Geodynamics and Geology
Award.AbstractNarration:
1347184
Wessel

This EAR Geoinformatics Program (NSF 11-581) grant supports a three year project to develop enhancements to the Generic Mapping Tools (GMT) software package for analyzing and displaying geoscience data. GMT now includes more than 80 modules that share a common set of command options, file structures, and documentation. It is used widely to produce publication-quality graphic presentations. GMT now has more than 25,000 individual registered users. This award will support expansion on GMT capabilities to include: 1) code for plotting, velocity vectors from GPS measurements and their uncertainties as arrows with confidence ellipses, earthquake focal mechanisms as hemispherical projections on cartographically correct maps, ternary diagrams and geologic symbols; 2) an Application Programming Interface (API) between GMT and Python to support computational workflow scripting; and 3) tools for Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) processing and analysis for spatially resolved imaging of Earth surface deformation associated with earthquake-generating faults, active volcanoes, moving glaciers, and unstable landslides, as well as the engineered withdrawal and/or injection of petroleum, natural gas, geothermal fluids, and carbon dioxide. The developed GMT source code will be distributed, free of charge, under the GNU Lesser General Public License.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interferometric analysis of synthetic aperture radar images (InSAR) is a method for measuring deformation of the Earth's (ground) surface. This geodetic technique calculates the interference pattern caused by the difference in phase between two images acquired by a satellite radar sensor at two distinct times. The resulting data product, called an interferogram, is a contour map of the change in distance between the ground and the radar instrument. These maps provide a spatial sampling density of more than 100 pixels per square kilometer, a precision of the order of 10 millimeters, a registration accuracy of approximately 10 meters, and an observation cadence of around 1 pass per week, depending on the satellite. This remote-sensing tool has been demonstrated and validated for many actively deforming areas, including those affected by earthquakes, volcanoes, glaciers, and anthropogenic production of fluids. 

To calculate interferograms, the collaborative project has developed and implemented a set of software tools called GMT5SAR. The code, installation instructions, documentation, and sample data sets are available at the GMT5SAR WIKI (http://gmt.soest.hawaii.edu/projects/gmt5sar). The GMT5SAR package is fully integrated with the Generic Mapping Tools (GMT) that is also publicly available as open-source software at https://github.com/GenericMappingTools

Using GMT5SAR, one can produce hundreds of pairwise interferometric combinations (interferograms) in a nearly automated way. Since each interferometric pair can be computed as an individual thread, multiple pairs can be computed in parallel. In other words, the workflow forms a directed, acyclic graph (DAG). 
To automate the analysis of InSAR data, the project team has implemented a workflow as a set of command files that run on the Center for High Throughput Computing (CHTC at UW-Madison), a subset of the Open Science Grid, in a high-throughput computing (HTC) environment using a scheduling language known as HTCondor (https://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/).  

The high-throughput workflow handles the following tasks:

(1) Automatic, unattended downloading of data providers via the Seamless SAR Archive (SSARA) https://www.unavco.org/projects/past-projects/ssara/ssara.html; 

(2) Pre-processing data files to establish a data base of metadata;

(3) Sorting input files by sensor, track, frame, and date;

(4) Evaluating the success (or failure) of an individual job (producing a single interferometric pair from raw or SLC data);

(5) Exporting high-level, geocoded data products in standard formats (e.g., GeoTiff, KML, NetCDF).

The command files are available in the public domain as open-source software at https://github.com/ecreinisch/bin_htcondor

To model the deformation fields mapped by InSAR, we estimate the optimal values of the parameters in a geophysical model using the General Inversion of Phase Technique " GIPhT. One advantage of this approach is the ability to evaluate the statistical uncertainty of the estimated model parameters. To analyze multiple interferograms as a time series, one can use methods for "temporal adjustment" These methods reduce sets of interferograms spanning irregular intervals of time to series of range change measurements at the points in time (epochs) when the images were acquired. 

The (Matlab) source code for GIPhT is available to the public under the GNU Lesser General Public License at https://github.com/feigl/gipht

The GMT5SAR and GIPhT software workflows have been used in a research project to image a geothermal field. Called PoroTomo, the project has an over-arching goal of improving the efficiency of renewable geothermal resources for generating electricity. The full name of the project is "Poroelastic Tomography by Adjoint Inverse Modeling of Data from Seismology, Geodesy, and Hydrology". 

A female graduate student in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) has been trained for a career in research at the intersection of two disciplines: geophysics and computer science.  She has completed her Ph.D. She plans a post-doctoral fellowship at a national laboratory.
